subject: Re: JUnit timeout - how to change timeout?
msgSnippet: ... [snip] ... (??) ... Right, you ll need to do a little work to get JUnit to get any failed assertions back to JUnit.  Or use one of the test classes
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "ma_lac84" <martilaszlo@...> wrote:
[snip]
> cycle is an infinite one. At a moment (let's say, after 2 or 3 time
> processing of the instructions in the while cycle) the testing
> terminates, without any exception rasing, or error message, the
> application simply stops. I suppose is something about timeout...
(??)
>

Right, you'll need to do a little work to get JUnit to get any failed
assertions back to JUnit. Or use one of the test classes discussed
in the links below. By itself, JUnit doesn't have a timeout, for
example, but check out Matt Albrecht's GroboUtils (see link below),
that in fact is supported, so you aren't left hanging because of a
runaway thread.

This leads into another point: in addition to Simon's points, I'd
also suggest that, in keeping with the philosophy of JUnit, you try
to make your test run quickly, perhaps by configuring parameters, or
sing mock objects, etc.

Matt Albrecht has written a good review of the issue, including
source code, and includes a reference to Andy Schneider's original
JavaWorld article:
http://today.java.net/pub/a/today/2003/08/06/multithreadedTests.html

Other tips from this newsgroup:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/17611
